The Thylacine: The Thylacine, also known as the Tasmanian Tiger, was a marsupial carnivore that was native to Australia and Tasmania. It is often considered one of the most iconic extinct animals. The Great Auk: The Great Auk was a flightless bird that was native to the North Atlantic. It was a key food source for the indigenous people of the region. Bringing the Great Auk back to life could serve as a way to honor the cultural significance of the bird to the people who once lived in the area.

The Woolly Mammoth: The Woolly Mammoth was a large mammal that lived during the last Ice Age. It was well-adapted to cold environments and could potentially be brought back to life to help combat climate change. The mammoth's ability to withstand cold temperatures could be an important asset in preserving habitats in the Arctic and other regions that are experiencing rapid climate change.

The Passenger Pigeon: The Passenger Pigeon was a migratory bird that was once one of the most abundant bird species in North America. It became extinct in 1914 due to overhunting and the clearing of its forest habitat. Bringing the Passenger Pigeon back to life could help restore the biodiversity of the region and provide a source of food for other species.

The Moa: The Moa was a large flightless bird that was native to New Zealand. It was hunted to extinction by the indigenous people of the region. Bringing the Moa back to life could help preserve the unique biodiversity of New Zealand and provide a source of food for other species.
